metadata.title: Use PostgresNIO to store your Todos in a Postgres database

sections.title: Use PostgresNIO to store your Todos in a Postgres database

inlineContent.text: Now we have a working API and a way to test it, lets look into storing our todos in a Postgres database with PostgresNIO.
Setup a Postgres database to use with the Todos application.
You’ll need to install postgres on your system if you don’t already have it. Detailed instructions on installing Postgres can be found
Once you have installed Postgres follow the instructions on screen to start your Postgres database service.
The Postgres install comes with
the commandline interface to Postgres. We are going to use this to create a new database and a new role.
Note the SQL commands all end in a semi-colon. The
command connects to a database and the
command quits
. You can find out more about
We return to our project…
And add PostgresNIO as a dependency
Let’s return to
in Todos.swift…
And setup a client to connect to Postgres. We are going to use
from PostgresNIO. The
flag is used to decide on whether we should setup the
. Note the configuration details are the same as the Postgres role we set up earlier.
Currently
doesn’t have a full release and is only available with
. Hopefully this will change in the near future.
sets up background processes that require lifecycle management. You can add a service to
to have its lifecycle managed as long as it conforms to
. This is done by adding it to an internally held
. More details on
and
can be found in the documentation for
Unfortunately
does not conform to
so we cannot add it as a Service.
Instead we create a wrapper
that runs the client and cancels it when a graceful shutdown signal is received.
Now if we add
to the
the client’s lifecycle is managed.
Implement a version of
that uses
We start our Postgres support by creating a type conforming to
that uses
from PostgresNIO. The functions are filled out with dummy code just now so the project will compile.
If we are going to be saving our todos to a database we are going to need a table to store them in.
I won’t go into any great detail about the SQL calls. That is not the purpose of this tutorial. We will cover how you construct, send calls and parse their results with
as we proceed through the tutorial.
Return to Todos.swift…
Use the newly created
and once the
is running call
Back to TodoPostgresRepository.swift to start implementing our repository methods.
The
method gives you an idea of how the
works. You lease a Postgres connection using
, it runs your queries inside the closure and then releases the connection back to the connection pool once they are done.
Wait a sec! If you look closer that query looks like it’s got SQL injection. That’s a classic security issue. Except this isn’t the case here. The object being constructed is not a
but a
which uses
to create parameter bindings for all the interpolated variables.
The

method demonstrates how you get data returned from a query. The query returns a sequence of rows. You extract the data from the row by decoding it as a tuple. In this case there should only be one row so we return immediately as soon as we have it.
is very similar to
. Except there is no
clause in the SQL and we return all of the rows returned from the query instead of just the first.
has a complication where we only want to include the non optional values in the
query otherwise we’ll be setting database columns to null. You could do this dynamically and build a
bit by bit but it is safer just to provide the full query strings for each situation.
And finally the
and
functions. This completes the implementation of the Postgres todos repository.
If you go to TodosTests.swift…
You can switch the
boolean to false to test your Postgres solution.
That’s us done, we have a working and tested Todos application.

abstract.text: Now we have a working API and a way to test it, lets look into storing our todos in a Postgres database with PostgresNIO.
Add some functionality to your app
A tutorial showing you how to build a simple Todos application that allows you to store, access, edit and delete Todos in a database, using Hummingbird and PostgresNIO.
Now we have a working API and a way to test it, lets look into storing our todos in a Postgres database with PostgresNIO.

func update(id: UUID, title: String?, order: Int?, completed: Bool?) async throws -> Todo? {

// UPDATE query. Work out query based on whick values are not nil
// The string interpolations are building a PostgresQuery with bindings and is safe from sql injection
query = "UPDATE todos SET title = \(title), order = \(order), completed = \(completed) WHERE id = \(id)"
query = "UPDATE todos SET title = \(title), order = \(order) WHERE id = \(id)"
query = "UPDATE todos SET title = \(title), completed = \(completed) WHERE id = \(id)"
query = "UPDATE todos SET title = \(title) WHERE id = \(id)"
query = "UPDATE todos SET order = \(order), completed = \(completed) WHERE id = \(id)"
query = "UPDATE todos SET order = \(order) WHERE id = \(id)"
query = "UPDATE todos SET completed = \(completed) WHERE id = \(id)"
// SELECT so I can get the full details of the TODO back
// The string interpolation is building a PostgresQuery with bindings and is safe from sql injection
for try await(id, title, order, url, completed) in stream.decode((UUID, String, Int?, String, Bool?).self, context: .default) {
return Todo(id: id, title: title, order: order, url: url, completed: completed)
